Temperature: Temperature increases as the level of greenhouse effect increases.  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: More volcanoes dump more CO2 into the atmosphere.  Because the carbon sinks take a long time to react (~100,000 years), CO2 sources exceed CO2 sinks, causing the atmospheric CO2 level to rise.
Volcano: An increase in volcanic activity is the forcer in this scenario.  We allow it to move from level 1 to level 2 in 100-200 years.  In almost all real cases, it will actually take a much longer time to change.
Sea: Rising temperature raises sea level quickly (due to thermal expansion--which changed sea level in this scenario). Melting glacial ice and volcanic activity also raise sea level, but response times are longer.
Weathering C Burial: Rising temperature raises evaporation and precipitation, which increases weathering rates.  However, it will take longer to respond.
CO3 Desposition: Rising weathering rates increase carbonate deposition (more C and Ca are washed to the oceans), but response times are long (~100,000 years)
Sediment: C burial by sediments, buried C release, Insolation, and Mountains likely won't change enough to have an effect in this scenario.

Temperature: Temperature increases as the level of greenhouse effect increases.  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: In 100,000 years, CO2 levels have increased since the volcanic source has increased and the C sinks are just beginning to respond at this time scale.
Volcano: An increase in volcanic activity is the forcer in this scenario.  It rises from very low (level 1) to medium (level 3) in 100,000 years.  This is a very rapid change in volcanism.
Ice: Rising temperatures will melt a significant part of this planet's ice during this 100,000 year period.
Sea: Rising temperature raises sea level quickly (but didn't play much of a role during this time period). Melting glacial ice and volcanic activity (if due to higher mid-ocean ridge activity) also raise sea level, and will do so during this time scale.  These two processes caused most of the change during this time interval.
Weathering C Burial: Rising temperature raises evaporation and precipitation, which increases weathering rates.
CO3 Desposition: Rising weathering rates increase carbonate deposition, which responses in ~100,000 years.

Temperature: Temperature increases as the level of greenhouse effect increases.    Since CO2 level has now reached a maximum, so will the planet's temperature.
CO2: During this time interval, C removal (carbonate deposition) catches up to the increased C source.
Volcano: An increase in volcanic activity is the forcer in this scenario.  In this scenario, volcanism reaches its maximum level (5) and will stay constant for the rest of the simulation.
Ice: All of the planet's ice melted during this period.  Because all the ice melted, the planet's albedo is as low as it can get.  As a result, the planet's temperature remains high, even when CO2 levels begin to slowly drop.
Sea: Sea level reaches its maximum height due to the high temperatures, high volcanic rate, and no polar ice.
Weathering C Burial: Rising temperature raises evaporation and precipitation, which increases weathering rates.  Weathering rate tops out during this time scale.
CO3 Desposition: Weathering is now providing the maximum amount of raw materials to make carbonate (given the low level of mountains).  Carbonate deposition is now maximized.

Temperature: Temperature increases as the level of greenhouse effect increases.  Since atmopsheric CO2 level begins to slowly decline, temperature remains very high but come down a level and stablize.
CO2: During this time interval, C removal (due to carbonate deposition) surpasses the volcanic source rate of CO2.  The CO2 level remains high, but begins to slowly decrease, coming down a level over several million years.
Ice: Even though temperature declined over this time period, the planet remains ice free, primarily because of the ice-albedo feedback cycle.
Sea: Even though the planet remains ice-free, sea level comes down.  This is primarily due to the decrease in temperature.  As the planet cools, ocean water takes up less volume, causing a drop in sea level.
Weathering C Burial: Cooling temperature lowers evaporation and precipitation, which decreases weathering rates.
CO3 Desposition: Dropping weathering rates decreases carbonate deposition as less C and Ca are washed to the oceans.
